page.title: 09GRETA BRIDGE
page.content: The R.Greta rushes down from Stainmore and joins the R.Tees just below Rokeby at the Meeting of the Waters. The Romans forded the river as had the Celts before them. The present crossing, by a high dual carriageway bridge opened as part of the by-pass of the village in 1976. The by-pass was made necessary because the A66 had deviated from the direct line of the Romans and wound inconveniently to the south to cross the river at a splendid Georgian stone built bridge (the subject of a famous water colour by J S Cotman). The deviation was inconvenient to drivers and residents alike. The passing motorist hated the mile long meander, especially if he was unfortunate enough to arrive just behind a heavy lorry crawling to negotiate bends and hills.
